title: Part A
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe the trend in the percentage of electricity produced using nuclear energy in the United States between 1990 and 2015, such as any of the following:

· The trend in the percentage of nuclear power produced in the United States has remained relatively constant/relatively the same from 1990 to 2015.

· The nuclear power produced in the United States has remained around 20% of the total electricity produced from 1990 to 2015.

The response describes the trend in the percentage of electricity produced using nuclear energy in the United States between 1990 and 2015, such as one of the following:

· The trend in the percentage of nuclear power produced in the United States has remained relatively constant/relatively the same from 1990 to 2015.

· The nuclear power produced in the United States has remained around 20% of the total electricity produced from 1990 to 2015.

title: Part B
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not identify the most recent year during which Japan produced a greater percentage of its electricity from nuclear energy than did Germany or the United States, such as any of the following:

· 2010

· 2011

title: Part C
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not explain how the United States could have used more nuclear fuel than Japan when the graph is showing similar trends for both countries such as the following:

· The graph is comparing percent not total electricity production. The United States generated more electricity/used more energy than Japan in the 1990s. Therefore more nuclear fuel was required to produce the proportion generated by nuclear power plants in the United States.

The response explains how the United States could have used more nuclear fuel than Japan when the graph is showing similar trends for both countries such as the following:

· The graph is comparing percent not total electricity production. The United States generated more electricity/used more energy than Japan in the 1990s. Therefore more nuclear fuel was required to produce the proportion generated by nuclear power plants in the United States.

title: Part D
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not make a claim based on evidence that supports or refutes the statement that the 1973 oil crisis led to an increased investment in nuclear power in France such as the following:

· The significant increase shown in the graph in nuclear power electricity generation in France beginning in 1978 supports this claim. Prior to 1978, less than 10% of electricity generated in France came from nuclear power. Then the percentage of electricity generated by nuclear power increased to 70% by the mid-1980s.

The response makes a claim based on evidence that supports or refutes the statement that the 1973 oil crisis led to an increased investment in nuclear power in France such as the following:

· The significant increase shown in the graph in nuclear power electricity generation in France beginning in 1978 supports this claim. Prior to 1978, less than 10% of electricity generated in France came from nuclear power. Then the percentage of electricity generated by nuclear power increased to 70% by the mid-1980s.

title: Part E
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe why pairing solar energy with nuclear energy makes this renewable source a more viable method of electrical production for more United States consumers such as the following:

· Sunlight amount can fluctuate daily and seasonally. Electricity from a nuclear power plant can provide electricity at night, during cloudy days, or during the winter.

title: Part F

descriptions: The response does not identify an indoor air pollutant that could increase during the summer by opening windows and increasing the humidity inside the house as mold.

title: Part G
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe one way savings can occur by increasing the amount of vegetation in an urban landscape, such as any of the following:

· More sunlight will be reflected or absorbed by vegetation (more shade, higher albedo, reduced heat island effect), lowering the temperature of the city requiring less cooling.

· Increased transpiration will reduce city temperature requiring less cooling.

· Increased pedestrian/bike traffic leads to less fuel used in vehicles.

title: Part H
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe one economic benefit, other than energy cost savings, that may result from increasing the amount of vegetation in cities, such as any of the following:

· Increased property values in areas with increased vegetation.

· Sales of food produced in the city/urban gardens produces revenue.

· Increased local business revenues from increased tourism to green areas.

· Jobs created for vegetation planting and/or maintenance.

· Less money spent on water treatment from less polluted source water.

· Less money spent on repairing flood damage from less water run-off.

· Less pavement maintenance/replacement from less buckling.
